documents.content: A recent audit of claims processed through the Summit Health Network revealed discrepancies in billing for advanced imaging services. Patients aged 50-65 with spinal stenosis showed higher denial rates when referred by out-of-network providers. The report highlights inconsistent application of policy #SHN-4356 regarding prior authorizations for MRIs.

Riverside Orthopedics patient ID #PT-8842 (DOB 03/15/1968) was approved for lumbar epidural steroid injections following two prior denials. Documentation shows appeals success correlated with submission of detailed physical therapy progress notes from Fairview Rehabilitation Center.

New policy effective 10/01/2024 requires providers in the TN-12 region to use HealthBridge portal for all imaging pre-authorizations. This applies specifically to spinal procedures for patients over 45. Transition support available at (615) 442-8900 ext. 324.

Research note: Analysis of spinal stenosis treatment patterns shows 62% of patients receiving epidural injections required subsequent surgery within 3 years. Highest correlation found in cases where initial treatment was delayed beyond 6 weeks from diagnosis.

metadata.content_summary: Spinal stenosis treatment patterns, policy changes, and claims processing in the TN-12 region

questions.q: Which two medical providers were involved in the care of patient PT-8842?
questions.a: Riverside Orthopedics and Fairview Rehabilitation Center

questions.q: What new authorization process takes effect October 2024 in the TN-12 region and how does it affect patients aged 50-65 with spinal stenosis?
questions.a: HealthBridge portal for spinal pre-authorizations; patients 50-65 with spinal stenosis require it.

questions.q: What combination of factors helped patient PT-8842 successfully appeal treatment denials?
questions.a: Detailed PT notes and policy SHN-4356 inconsistencies.

questions.q: What demographic and policy factors correlate with higher MRI denial rates?
questions.a: Patients 50-65 with spinal stenosis and policy SHN-4356 inconsistencies.
